title: Work for Nissan? You're about to be given the Freedom of the City of Sunderland
text:
Work for Nissan? You're about to be given the Freedom of the City of Sunderland Sunderland councillors have voted unanimously to bestow the honour on the workforce of the car-plant Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get   
The entire workforce of Nissan’s plant in Sunderland is to be honoured with the Freedom of the City. 
Councillors have voted unanimously to bestow the ceremonial honour on the factory’s staff in light of Nissan’s decision to continue production in the region post-Brexit. 
Proposing the motion, the leader of the council, Paul Watson, said: “For the first time we have the real secret of Nissan’s success - it’s the workforce.” 
The official wording of the motion councillors voted on reads: “This council congratulates wholeheartedly the Nissan workforce for their sterling efforts in securing the future production of the next generation Qashqai and X-Trail and feels that it is right and proper for the workforce of Nissan to receive the Freedom of the City at a future date.” 
A firm date for when the award would be made official was not set. 
Nissan plays a pivotal role in the economy of Sunderland and the broader North East region. 
The largest car plant in the UK for 14 years and largest exporter of cars from the UK for 12 years, Nissan employs over 7000 people. 
There were serious concerns about the long-term future of the plant following the vote to leave the European Union. 
Nissan dramatically announced it would remain in Sunderland and increase production last month. 
How the government convinced Nissan to stay has come under much scrutiny, with questions raised about the nature of the assurances that were given to the Japanese manufacturing giant. 
It’s not the first time someone connected with Nissan has been honoured in this way. Nissan's plant in Sunderland (Photo: Owen Humphreys/PA Wire) 
Trevor Mann, Nissan’s Chief Performance Officer, was awarded the Freedom in 2014. 
Coun Watson paraphrased Trevor in last night’s council meeting, saying: “There is a spirit and enthusiasm that makes Sunderland a very special place. 
“Nissan’s successes would not have been possible without the people of Sunderland.” 
Councillor Peter Wood, leader of the Conservatives on the council, said: “It is right to recognise the contribution of the men and women who work at Nissan – on the production line, in the office and in the boardroom. 
“To confer the freedom of the city upon them is the best way we as councillors can show how proud we are of them for the pride they take in their work.” Read More 
Since the Freedom of the City honour was in introduced in 1901, many different people from different walks of life have been recognised. 
Originally, it was used primarily to honour soldiers who had served in the Boer War. 
After being revived in 2004 it has been awarded to a more varied group of recipients. 
The first of the new tranche of awards was given to HMS Ocean and her crew, a Royal Navy ship which was constructed on the Wear. 
Jimmy Montgomery and Niall Quinn have both been recognised for their service to Sunderland AFC and Peter Vardy, another notable figure from the automotive sector, has also been given the award. Like us on Facebook
